did.unittitle: Library Company of Philadelphia miscellaneous records

bioghist.p: The Library Company of Philadelphia is an independent research library concentrating on American society and culture from the 17th through 19th centuries. It was founded in 1731 by Benjamin Franklin as a subscription library supported by its shareholders, as it is to this day. Free and open to the public, the Library Company houses an extensive non-circulating collection of rare books, manuscripts, broadsides, ephemera, and works of art.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of miscellaneous materials related to the Library Company of Philadelphia. Materials include: awards and citations, including House of Representatives Citation from 1981, proclamation of James Logan Day (Oct 20th, 1974), and a membership certificate from the Huguenot Society of London (1901); broadside reproductions; scrapbooks compiled by Herbert Harley on: Button Gwinnett, Henry Hudson, and Governor Johann Printz; several first day issues of stamps; 1988 Library Company Christmas party photos; a Library Company cookbook; non-Library Company posters and oversize reproductions, including maps of Philadelphia and a calligraphic list of contributors to the Edwin Wolf Fund; humorous broadside "A Quart of Millennium"; Ben Wolf poem, 1988; gifts presented to John Van Horne on his 1986 visit to Italy; magazines and books containing references to Library Company materials, including Antiques Magazine, American Heritage, and National Geographic; books edited by Library Company staff; and Library Company seals. The collection also includes photographs, a silhouette, and a cartoon of Edwin Wolf.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
